title: Computer Networks & Internet
description: Learn about network fundamentals, internet services, and cybersecurity practices essential for the digital age.
subject: ict
achievementDescription: Master computer networks and internet concepts for safe and effective digital communication

text.introduction: Computer networks and the internet have revolutionized how we communicate, learn, and do business. In Ghana's digital transformation journey, understanding networks and internet technology is crucial for participating in the global digital economy and protecting personal information online.

sections.title: Network Fundamentals
sections.content: Computer networks connect devices to share resources and information. Network types include Local Area Networks (LANs) for small areas like homes or schools, and Wide Area Networks (WANs) that connect larger geographical areas. Network topology describes how devices are arranged, while protocols are rules that govern data transmission. The OSI model provides a framework for understanding network communication layers.

sections.title: Internet Services and Applications
sections.content: The internet offers various services including web browsing, email communication, social media platforms, and e-commerce. Web browsers access websites using HTTP/HTTPS protocols. Email systems use SMTP for sending and POP/IMAP for receiving messages. Social media platforms enable global communication and content sharing. E-commerce allows online buying and selling, transforming business practices worldwide.

sections.title: Network Security and Safety
sections.content: Cybersecurity protects networks and devices from threats like malware, phishing, and unauthorized access. Strong passwords, two-factor authentication, and regular software updates are essential security practices. Safe browsing habits include avoiding suspicious links, using secure websites (HTTPS), and being cautious with personal information. Understanding these practices helps protect against online threats.

questions.question: What does LAN stand for in computer networking?
questions.explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network, which connects devices in a small geographical area like a home, office, or school.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for secure web browsing?
questions.explanation: HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure) provides encrypted communication for secure web browsing.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a firewall in network security?
options: To block unauthorized access to networks
questions.explanation: A firewall acts as a barrier to block unauthorized access to networks while allowing legitimate traffic to pass through.

questions.question: Which of the following is a social media platform?
questions.explanation: Facebook is a social media platform that allows users to connect, share content, and communicate with others.

questions.question: What should you do if you receive a suspicious email asking for personal information?
options: Click on all links in the email
questions.explanation: Suspicious emails should be deleted without responding, as they may be phishing attempts to steal personal information.

exercises.title: Network Topology Diagrams
exercises.instructions: Label the components in these network diagrams: a simple home network, a school computer lab network, and a small business network.
exercises.hint: Identify devices like computers, routers, switches, and cables. Consider how data flows between devices.

exercises.title: OSI Model Layers
exercises.instructions: Label the seven layers of the OSI model and provide one example of what happens at each layer during data transmission.
exercises.hint: Start from the bottom (Physical) and work up to the top (Application). Think about what happens to data at each level.

exercises.title: Internet Service Matching
exercises.instructions: Match each internet service with its primary purpose: web browsing, email, social media, e-commerce, and online banking.
exercises.hint: Consider what each service is primarily used for. Some services may have multiple purposes.

exercises.title: Protocol Identification
exercises.instructions: Match each protocol with its function: HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, POP3, and FTP.
exercises.hint: Think about what each protocol does in network communication. Some are for web browsing, others for email or file transfer.

exercises.title: Cybersecurity Threat Recognition
exercises.instructions: Identify whether each scenario represents a cybersecurity threat: suspicious email links, software update notifications, public Wi-Fi networks, and strong passwords.
exercises.hint: Consider which scenarios could potentially compromise security and which are actually security measures.

exercises.title: Safe Browsing Practices
exercises.instructions: Identify which browsing practices are safe: using HTTPS websites, clicking on pop-up ads, sharing passwords with friends, and logging out of accounts on public computers.
practices: Logging out of accounts on public computers
exercises.hint: Think about which practices protect your information and which could expose you to security risks.
